title:
Role of obesity on all-cause mortality in whites with type 2
diabetes from Italy
author: Diapola
author_address: Research Unit of Diabetes and Endocrine Diseases, Poliambulatorio Giovanni Paolo II, IRCCS “Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza”, Viale Padre Pio, 71013, San Giovanni Rotondo, Italy
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on all cause mortality in people with type 2 diabetes
rationale: While there is no doubts that obesity is a major risk factor for all-cause mortality in otherwise healthy individuals [2], its role in patients with type 2 diabetes is controversial [3–7], with some studies showing a deleterious [4] and others a protective, paradoxical [6–8] effect.
outcome_population: European ancestry (whites from Apulia, central-southern Italy)
exposure_proxy: The supervised survival random forest algorithm was employed to impute missing SNPs data on such patients, on the basis of their mortality outcome [13]
n_SNP_difference_reason: Of the 32 SNPs, only used those whose risk allele increase in BMI was >=0.10 kg/m2 and allele frequency was >=10 % [11, 12] (n = 20). AND Only SNPs obeying Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium (HWE, n = 18) were used for further analyses
MR_sensitivity_method1: Re-ran analyses after excluding potentially pleiotropic snps
limitations_overall: No real limitations mentioned, just that can't rule out a false negative result due to small sample, and that there was no replication in another sample.

title: BMI and Mortality in UK Biobank: Revised Estimates Using Mendelian Randomization
author: Wade
author_address: MRC  Integrative  Epidemiology  Unit,  University  of  Bristol,  Bristol,  UK
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on mortality and cause specific mortality
rationale: Inconsistencies in previous literature regarding the risk of death from obestiy. Obesity paradox makes it appear that being overweight can be protective, however, this may be due to unmeasured confounding
outcome_definition: death certificates include the disease or condition stated to be the underlying cause of death, as well as other conditions, diseases, injuries or events contributing to death but not related to the disease or condition causing it. Data were provided as date of death (DoD), an integer value for age of death (AoD) and underlying (primary) cause of death in International Classification of Diseases (ICD)-10 codes for all deaths that occurred between the 10/05/2006 and 16/02/2016.
MR_sensitivity_method4: Re-ran analysis using subset of SNPs, having removed SNPs associated with potential confounders
outcome_units: risk of mortality by X time
limitations_overall: Not really discussed in overall terms
limitations_pleiotropy: analyses conducted in the current study provided little evidence of con- founding or pleiotropy and awarded greater confidence in the validity of the instrument used and, thus, MR-derived estimates. Notably, the GRS was associated (with very small effect sizes) with covariables. The sheer presence of an association between traditionally considered confounders with the GRS is interesting and could be because of (1) vertical pleiotropy (i.e., the GRS being associated with smoking sta- tus, for example, because of the potentially causal relationship between BMI and smoking) or (2) coincident genetic and phenotypic variation because of population structure or selection/collider bias; both reasons are increasingly easier to detect with the advent of very large studies such as UK Biobank (45).
limitations_population_stratification: analyses were restricted to those of White British ancestry, limiting the generalizability of results to other ancestral groups. Second, one cannot rule the coincident structure in both genotype and phenotype out of any potential biasing role in genetic analyses within a study of this scale. Lastly, the power to detect associations with MR analyses remains low for many mortality causes
limitations_statistical_power: Analyses of cancer-specific mortality in the current study were limited by the rarity of these deaths, accentuated further in sex-stratified analyses.
notes: 2SLS with Cox proportional hazard models as second stage
